questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant that contains a user named User1.
User1 needs to be able to search mailboxes and purge email.
To which role group should you add User1?

discussion.content: B is correct

Selected Answer: B
Better link with Matrix of Permissions: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/assign-ediscovery-permissions?view=o365-worldwide

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant that contains the users shown in the following table.
//IMG//

From Exchange Online PowerShell, Admin1 runs the New-OwaMailboxPolicy -Name Sales command.
From Exchange Online PowerShell, Admin 2 runs the Test-ClientAccessRule -User User2@contoso.com -AuthenticationType
BasicAuthentication -Protocol OutlookWebApp `"RemoteAddress 172.17.17.26 -RemotePort 443 command.
From the Exchange admin center, you export the admin audit log.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: When your export all results for an audit log search, the raw data from the unified audit log is copied to a comma-separated value (CSV) file that is downloaded to your local computer. This file contains additional information from each audit record in a column named AuditData.
YES, YES, NO

comments.content: Answer i correct. Log is in XML

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: No -
When you export entries from mailbox audit logs, Exchange Online saves the entries in an XML, not CSV, file and attaches it to an email message sent to the specified recipients.

Box 2: Yes -
Use the New-OwaMailboxPolicy cmdlet to create Outlook on the web mailbox policies.
This action is included in the admin audit log, as it adds a policy (rule) to the mailbox.

Box 3: No -
Use the Test-ClientAccessRule cmdlet to test how client access rules affect access to your organization. If any of the client properties you specify for this cmdlet match any client access rules, the rules are returned in the results.
This action is not included in the admin audit log, as it does not change the mailbox in any way.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/security-and-compliance/exchange-auditing-reports/export-mailbox-audit-logs https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/new-owamailboxpolicy https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/test-clientaccessrule

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B for sure. Connection filter is for IP (allow/block) and Safe List (not configurable)

Selected Answer: B
should edit spam filter policy and add the domain as safe

Selected Answer: B
spam filter policy not the connection filter

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
That safe list marked as an answer is not configurable. It's an on/off switch and MS maintains it - can't add details of a your partner organisation there.

obviously B
no mention of an IP in this question, so how would you configure the connection filter? add the domain to allow list in the spam filter

choices.D: Enable the Zero-hour auto purge (ZAP) email protection feature.
choices.C: Enable the safe list on a connection filter.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses a default domain named contoso.com.
Users report that email messages from a domain named fabrikam.com are identified as spam even though the messages are legitimate.
You need to prevent messages from fabrikam.com from being identified as spam.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Client access Rule is the correct for sure
It should be Client Access Rules

Selected Answer: A
You should use A (CondAccess) with named locations.

comments.content: Could also use C I guess

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Why not A?
Client Access Rule can only block access to the classic EAC per https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/clients-and-mobile-in-exchange-online/client-access-rules/client-access-rules

Selected Answer: C
For this moment - Client Access Rule
Best Answer should be Client Access Rule "C" https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/clients-and-mobile-in-exchange-online/client-access-rules/client-access-rules
i would go with C

questions.question_text:
Your company has the offices and subnets shown in the following table.
//IMG//

Each office has an IT department.
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant.
You need to ensure that only users in the IT department who sign in from the London office can access the Exchange admin center.
What should you use?

questions.answer_description:
Step 1: a sensitive label -
Step 2: a data loss prevention (DLP) policy
Configuring sensitive info types for a label
When you select the Sensitive info types option, you see the same list of sensitive information types as when you create a data loss prevention (DLP) policy. So you can, for example, automatically apply a Highly Confidential label to any content that contains customers' personal information, such as credit card numbers, social security numbers, or passport number

Step 3: an auto-label policy -
The Azure Information Protection unified labeling client supports automatic labeling for built-in and custom sensitive info types.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/apply-sensitivity-label-automatically?view=o365-worldwide
questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have a Microsoft 365 tenant.
You need to implement a compliance solution that meets the following requirements:
✑ A sensitivity label named ContainsCreditCardinfo must be applied to all Microsoft Office documents that contain credit card information.
✑ When a document that has the label applied is attached to an email by a user, the user must receive a policy tip in Microsoft Outlook.
Which three objects should you create in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
NOTE: More than one order of answer choices is correct. You will receive credit for any of the correct orders you select.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
I’d go with ….
1.Sensitivity Label >> To define the document types (Confidential, Secret, Public,…)
2.Auto Labeling >> To automatically apply sensitivity labels to email messages containing Card Info
3.Label Policy >> To group labels, define the Scope and behavior (ie: required for mails)

I think this should be the answer.


1. a label policy; to create ContainCreditCardinfo
2. an auto-labeling policy; to apply the label on aything that contains credit card info.
3. DLP policy; condition 
 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ypQmB3F2uF0
 https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/use-notifications-and-policy-tips?view=o365-worldwide
